# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

You can solve this task using the following function in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, Pandas, DataStructures

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df_filtered = filter(r -> r.manufacturer == "audi" && (r.model == "a4" || r.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    for i in 1:size(df, 1)
        if df[i, :manufacturer] == "audi" && (df[i, :model] == "a4" || df[i, :model] == "a4 quattro")
            df_filtered[i, :audi_a4_type] = true
        end
    end
    
    return df_filtered
end
```

This function first filters the input DataFrame `df` to only include rows where the `manufacturer` is "audi" and the `model` is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". Then it iterates over the filtered DataFrame, checking each row to see if the `manufacturer` is "audi" and the `model` is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". If these conditions are met, it sets the value in column `audi_a4_type` for that row to `true`.

You can then call this function with your DataFrame like so:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])

df_filtered = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
